metadata.title: An integrated process for production of jet-fuel range olefins from ethylene using Ni-AlSBA-15 and Amberlyst-35 catalysts

Scheme 1 Schematic of integrated production of C10+ oligomers from ethylene. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 (A) Small angle, (B) wide angle X-ray diffraction patterns, (C) TEM and SEM (inset) images of SBA-15, AlSBA-15, and Ni-AlSBA-15 catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (A) 29Si, and (B) 27Al MAS NMR of SBA-15, AlSBA-15, and Ni-AlSBA-15 catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Effect of (A) WHSV, (B) temperature, (C) C2H4 pressure, and (D) reaction time on the activity and product distribution profiles of Ni-AlSBA-15; Conditions: catalyst weight: 1g, WHSV: 0.375–0.899h−1, temperature: 150–200°C, C2H4 pressure: 5–15bar, and reaction time: up to 60h. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Effect of (A) catalyst loading, (B) temperature, (C) reaction time, (D) N2 pressure, and (E) Amberlyst-35 dry catalysts on the olefin distribution. Catalyst: Amberlyst-35 dry, oligomeric mixture: 10g, catalyst loading: 2.5–10wt%, temperature: 80–120°C, reaction time: 12–48h, and N2 pressure: 10–30bar. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TGA profiles of fresh, regenerated, and used Amberlyst-35 dry catalysts. Fig. 5 Table 1 Textural properties of SBA-15, AlSBA-15, and Ni-AlSBA-15 catalysts. Table 1 Catalyst d(nm) a0 (nm) D(nm) SBET (m2/g) V(cm3/g) Vmes (cm3/g) Vs (cm3/g) t(nm) SBA-15 10.1 11.66 8.0 714 1.00 0.62 0.38 4.2 AlSBA−15 a 9.6 11.08 6.9 411 0.63 0.38 0.25 4.5 Ni-AlSBA−15 a , b 9.5 10.97 6.9 417 0.68 0.41 0.27 4.4 d-spacing (d), cell parameter (a0), pore diameter (D), total pore volume (V), specific surface area (SBET), mesoporous volume (Vmes), secondary porosity volume (Vs), and wall thickness (t). The total acidity by NH3 TPD: 0.76mmol/g. a Si/Al=9.0 (mol/mol). b 1.9wt% Ni and 3.8wt% Al. Feature Article An integrated process for production of jet-fuel range olefins from ethylene using Ni-AlSBA-15 and Amberlyst-35 catalysts B. Hari Babu a Maeum Lee a Dong Won Hwang a b ⁎ Youngmin Kim a Ho-Jeong Chae a b ⁎ a Carbon Resources Institute, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology (KRICT), 141 Gajeongro, Yuseoung, Daejeon 305-600, Republic of Korea Carbon Resources Institute Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology (KRICT) 141 Gajeongro Yuseoung Daejeon 305-600 Republic of Korea b Department of Green Chemistry & Biotechnology, University of Science and Technology (UST), 113 Gwahangno, Yuseong, Daejeon 305-333, Republic of Korea Department of Green Chemistry & Biotechnology University of Science and Technology (UST) 113 Gwahangno Yuseong Daejeon 305-333 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Carbon Resources Institute, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology (KRICT), 141 Gajeongro, Yuseoung, Daejeon 305-600, Republic of Korea. Carbon Resources Institute Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology (KRICT) 141 Gajeongro Yuseoung Daejeon 305-600 Republic of Korea Graphical abstract An integrated process for the production of jet-fuel range olefins from ethylene was established by combining oligomerization of ethylene over the bifunctional Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst with subsequent co-oligomerization of the liquid oligomer mixture over an Amberlyst-35 ion-exchange resin catalyst. The mesoporous Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst was prepared by alumination of SBA-15 using sodium aluminate, followed by sequential ion exchange with NH4 + and Ni2+ ions. The Ni-AlSBA-15 (1.9wt% Ni and Si/Al=9) catalyst showed good catalytic activity, yielding over 99% ethylene conversion with non-Schulz-Flory type distribution of the generated hydrocarbons (C8 >C6 >C4 >C10+) and high stability at 200°C and 10bar at a weight hourly space velocity of 0.375h−1 for 60h. Co-oligomerization of the as-synthesized liquid oligomer mixture over Amberlyst-35 ion-exchange resin under the optimized reaction conditions (5wt% catalyst loading, 100°C, 30bar N2, and 24h of reaction time) generated greater than 98% C5+ liquid product, where the C10+ olefins constituted about 42%. The catalytic activity of the Amberlyst-35 catalyst used was almost identical to that of the fresh catalyst after washing with n-heptane and drying. Keywords Ethylene Oligomerization Jet-fuel Ni-Al-SBA-15 Amberlyst-35 1 Introduction Ethylene is one of the most important basic organic chemicals, the annual production of which currently exceeds 140 million tons [1]. Ethylene is conventionally produced by steam thermal cracking of gaseous or liquid saturated hydrocarbons in the petrochemical industry. On the other hand, emerging methods involving alternative sources such as natural gas, coal, and biomass have demonstrated industrial potential [1–3]. For example, methanol can be efficiently converted into ethylene (by a zeolite-catalyzed methanol-to-olefin (MTO) process) [4,5] and/or bio-ethanol to ethylene [6] as very promising processes. The oligomerization of light olefins is an important route for the production of linear and branched higher olefins; these olefins are used in the manufacture of detergents, petrochemicals, oil additives, high-octane ecological gasoline, etc. For jet fuel application, the catalytic oligomerization of ethylene to C10+ is very important [7]. Oligomerization of ethylene can be efficiently carried out by using homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. Commercially, these higher olefins are manufactured via ethylene oligomerization using homogeneous transition metal catalysts [8–10]. For instance, in the shell higher olefin process (SHOP), Ni complexes are used to generate higher olefins in the range of C4 to C20+ [8,9], whereas the Sabic/Linde Alpha-SABLIN process utilizes zirconium with an alkyl aluminum co-catalyst [9,10]. In the past decades, several new and effective homogeneous catalysts (i.e., complexes of Ni, Cr, Zr, Ta, Ti, Hf, Co, Fe, and W) have been developed [11–14]. However, these homogeneous catalysts usually suffer from several drawbacks such as difficulty in separation from the product, limited reusability, and sensitivity to impurities. To overcome these problems, heterogeneous catalysts have been developed by affixing the organometallic complexes to supports such as silica [15] and MCM-41 [16]. However, these kinds of systems are less active, as well as less stable, than their homogeneous counterparts [15]. Various Ni-containing porous materials, including Ni-exchanged amorphous silica-alumina [17,18], Ni/sulfated alumina [19], Ni-zeolites [20–23], Ni-AlMCM-41 [2,24,25], and Ni-AlSBA-15 [3,26] have been reported as efficient catalysts for the oligomerization of ethylene. Furthermore, the activity (i.e., ethylene conversion) of these Ni-based catalysts is determined by the number of accessible Ni sites, whereas the stability, carbon number distribution, and final structure of the oligomers depends on the density and strength of the Brønsted acid sites and the porosity. For example, Ni-exchanged zeolites (Ni-Y and Ni-MCM-22) were very rapidly deactivated due to blockage of their micropores with heavier oligomers [2,24,25]. Lallemand et al. [21] reported that the Ni-exchanged MCM-36 zeolite exhibited higher activity and stability than the Ni-exchanged MCM-22 zeolite due to the mesoporous nature of the MCM-36 zeolite that facilitates the diffusion of larger oligomers formed during the reaction. Subsequently, Ni-exchanged catalysts with larger pores, such as Ni-SiO2-Al2O3 [17,18], Ni-AlMCM-41 [2,27], and Ni-AlMCM-48 [28], were found to be very active and resistant to deactivation. Lately, Andrei et al. [3] reported that the Ni-exchanged AlSBA-15 catalysts were the most promising catalysts for ethylene oligomerization in terms of activity and stability in both batch and flow mode due to their interconnected mesopores, which are large enough to allow movement of the heavier oligomers, resulting in a lower deactivation rate. According to the literature [2,3,24,28], most of the catalytic systems produced hydrocarbons with the Schulz-Flory type distribution (i.e., C4 >C6 >C8 >C10+), whereas obtaining hydrocarbons with chains longer than ten carbon atoms, which are the major constituents of high-quality jet or diesel fuels, is much more difficult. Recently, Hulea et al. [2] proposed a catalytic cascade reaction for producing jet fuel range olefins in a gas-slurry reactor, where ethylene is oligomerized over Ni-AlMCM-41 to C4−C10 olefins with Schulz-Flory type distribution, and successive oligomerization of these olefins to higher olefins in the distillate range was carried out over H-AlMCM-41 in semicontinuous mode. This study focuses on the oligomerization of ethylene to C10+-rich oligomers by combination of a Ni-based bifunctional catalyst and ion-exchange resins (Scheme 1 ). In the present process, ethylene is first oligomerized over Ni-AlSBA-15 to obtain C8+-rich olefins with non-Schulz-Flory type distribution in a continuous fixed bed reaction system at low pressures (<15bar), which conditions are more advantageous than the previously reported conditions (>30bar) in terms of catalyst stability and production of non-Schulz-Flory type distribution. In the second step, the liquid-phase C8+-rich olefins are then co-oligomerized to C10+-rich olefins over Amberlyst-35 dry ion-exchange resin under batch reaction conditions. Through these new findings, an integrated process for the production of jet-fuel range olefins from ethylene can be established by combining two processes, i.e., oligomerization of ethylene over Ni-AlSBA-15 and co-oligomerization of the oligomeric mixture over Amberlyst-35 dry ion-exchange resin. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts The Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst was prepared according to the previously reported procedure [3]. In a typical synthesis, the final Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst was obtained in a sequence of three steps. In the first step, pure siliceous SBA-15 was synthesized in water using the (EO)20(PO)70(EO)20 triblock copolymer (Pluronic P123, Aldrich), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, Aldrich), and 2M HCl (Samchun Chemical), with a molar ratio of TEOS/P123/HCl/H2O=1/0.016/4.9/40.5. The mixture was stirred at 40°C for 24h and subsequently maintained at 100°C for 48h in a Teflon-lined autoclave under static conditions. The formed solid product was filtered, washed with water, and dried in an oven at 80°C for 15h. The final SBA-15 powder was obtained by calcination at 550°C for 8h under an air flow. In the second step, Al-SBA-15 was prepared from SBA-15 silica by grafting with sodium aluminate (34–39% Al2O3, KANTO Chemical) according to the procedure described by Luan and coworkers [29]. In a typical experiment, SBA-15 (5.5g) was suspended in 400ml of aqueous solution containing 1.50g of sodium aluminate (corresponding to a ratio of Si/Al=5) under stirring at room temperature for 15h. The sample, which generated the sodium form (Na-AlSBA-15), was filtered, washed with water, dried at 80°C for 15h, and then calcined at 550°C for 6h in air to generate Na-AlSBA-15. In the final step, 2g of Na-AlSBA-15 was treated thrice with 100ml of 0.5M aqueous solution of NH4NO3 at 30°C for 2h under constant agitation to obtain the ammonium form (i.e., NH4-AlSBA-15) and the sample in the ammonium form was then subjected to consecutive nickel-ion exchange using a 0.5M aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O by following the same procedure as above. The exchanged sample was dried at 80°C for 12h and then calcined at 550°C for 5h to attain the final Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst. Amberlyst-35 dry ion exchange resin was obtained from Rohm and Haas and used as received. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts The compositions of the catalysts were determined by elemental analysis using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP–AES) with a Thermo Scientific iCAP 6500 instrument. X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalysts were obtained on a Miniflex (Rigaku Corporation, Japan) using Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation (1.5406Å). The samples were scanned from 2θ=0.5 to 5° in steps of 0.02° at 45kV and 200mA for small angle analysis and from 2θ=10 to 80° at a scan speed of 2°min−1 at 30kV and 15mA for wide angle analysis. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were acquired at −196°C using a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 instrument. The samples were dehydrated under vacuum at 150°C for 12h prior to the analysis. The specific surface areas (S BET) were evaluated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method. The pore diameters, D, were measured from using the NLDFT method. The total pore volume, V, was determined from the end of the capillary condensation region of the isotherm. The mesopore volume, V mes (due to the main channels only), the secondary pore volume, Vs (microporosity and inter-mesopore connection volume), and the wall thickness, t, were calculated by using the following equations [3,30]: V mes =(D/1.05a0)2 (V +1/ρsi); V S = V ̶ V mes; t =a0 ̶ 0.95D, where ρSi is the density of amorphous silica (2.2gcm−3) and a0 is the cell parameter (a0 =2d 100/√3, from the XRD results). The morphological properties of the catalysts were studied via scanning electron microscopy (Tescan Mira 3 LMU FEG at an accelerating voltage of 10kV) and via transmission electron microscopy (TECNAI G2 RETROFTI). 27Al MAS NMR spectra were recorded for the calcined samples at room temperature with a Bruker 300MHz WB Premium Shielded spectrometer using an aqueous solution of Al(NO3)3 as an external reference with a 2μs pulse width and a 1s recycle delay. 29Si MAS NMR spectra were also recorded on a Bruker 300MHz spectrometer using Si(CH3)4 as an external reference with a 2μs pulse width and a 15s recycle delay. All the samples were fully hydrated before the measurement [29]. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (TPD-NH3) was performed using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 V3.05 system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). About 40mg of catalyst was pretreated at 300°C for 2h under He flow (30mlmin−1). The catalyst was then exposed to 10% NH3 balance He gas for 1h at 100°C. The physisorbed NH3 was removed under He flow for 1h at the same temperature. The temperature of the sample was then raised to 800°C at a heating rate of 10Kmin−1. The desorbed NH3 gas was monitored with a gas chromatograph using a thermal conductivity detector. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the catalysts was performed on a Sinco TGA-N 1000 thermal analyzer in the range of 30–800°C at a heating rate of 10Kmin−1 under a constant flow of nitrogen at 20 ml·min−1. 2.3 Oligomerization of ethylene Ethylene oligomerization was performed in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor (length: 300mm, O.D.: 9.5mm, I.D.: 7.5mm) using 1g of catalyst (0.15–0.25mm sieve fraction) within the temperature range of 150–200°C with a C2H4 pressure of 5–15bar and weight hourly space velocities (WHSVs) from 0.375 to 0.899h−1. Prior to the catalytic run, the catalysts were pretreated in situ under a flow of N2 (60mlmin−1) at 550°C for 8h. Afterwards, the reactor was cooled to room temperature under a N2 flow and the reactor was then pressurized with C2H4 (99.999% pure). Once the reaction pressure was reached and stabilized, the reactor temperature was then increased to the desired reaction temperature with the minimum C2H4 flow and the reaction started and continued under those conditions. The liquid products formed during the reaction were condensed in two traps located at the bottom of the reactor and kept at the reaction pressure (before the pressure control valve) and maintained at −2.0°C. Uncondensed reaction products were regularly analyzed on-line using a gas chromatograph (Yonglin 6500 GC) equipped with a capillary column (Rt-Alumina BOND/Na2SO4 (5m, 0.53mm I.D., 10μm df) and 60/80 Carboxen 1000 (15ft.×1/8 in.×2.1mm I.D., stainless steel)) using both a flame ionization detector (FID) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD) with N2 as an internal standard. The products condensed in the two traps were collected at the end of the runs, weighed, and analyzed off-line by another gas chromatograph (Yonglin 6500 GC) equipped with a capillary column (Rtx-100-DHA (105m, 0.25mm I.D., 0.5μm df)) using a FID. The conversion of ethylene at a given time-on-stream (TOS) was calculated from the relative areas of the ethylene and N2 (internal standard) peaks at the reactor inlet and outlet attained in the TCD channel of the on-line GC analysis. The carbon number distribution of the produced oligomers was averaged for the overall experiment by merging the results of the on-line and off-line GC analyses. Co-oligomerization of the oligomeric mixture obtained by ethylene oligomerization was performed in a 100ml autoclave. In a typical experiment, the desired amount of catalyst was added to 10g of the oligomeric mixture and the reaction was continued under N2 pressure (i.e. 10–30bar) for the desired time (i.e. 12–48h). After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to −25°C using a dry-ice and acetone mixture. The liquid product was then collected, weighed, and analysed off-line using the same gas chromatograph used for the aforementioned liquid product analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Ni-Al-SBA-15 For ethylene oligomerization, Ni-AlSBA-15 was prepared according to a previously reported method [3]; this catalyst is highly active and stable compared to other Ni-based catalysts such as Ni-MCM-41, Ni-silica-alumina, and Ni-Y zeolite due to the large interconnected mesopores of SBA-15. The physicochemical data for the prepared Ni-SBA-15 were almost identical with the reported values [3,31], as summarized in Table 1 . The Si/Al mole ratio was 9.0 and there was no significant change in the Si/Al ratio after ion-exchange with Ni2+ ions. The Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst contained around 1.9wt% Ni and 3.8wt% Al. From these results, it was clear that nearly 50% of the NH4 + ions were replaced by Ni2+ ions in the ion exchange process. Because of this partial exchange, the catalyst can exhibit Brønsted type acidity due to the formation of protons through the thermal decomposition of unexchanged ammonium species. The total acidity of the catalyst determined by NH3-TPD was 0.76mmolg−1. The small and wide-angle XRD patterns of Ni-AlSBA-15 showed reflections of the well-ordered two-dimensional (2D) hexagonal structure, which were in good agreement with the patterns reported for SBA-15 topology (Fig. 1 A). There was no significant change in the intensity of the XRD peaks of AlSBA-15 and Ni-AlSBA-15, clearly suggesting that the long range order of the mesopores was not affected by alumination or the Ni2+ ion exchange process. The slight shift in the peak positions might be due to blockage of the pores of SBA-15 by aluminum and nickel. Furthermore, only one broad diffraction peak was observed at 2θ=22° in the wide-angle XRD patterns (Fig. 1B) of all the catalysts, which is the characteristic peak of amorphous silica generally observed for mesoporous materials that consist of ordered channels in a non-crystalline matrix of silica [32,33]. No peaks corresponding to Al2O3 and NiO appeared in the profiles of AlSBA-15 and Ni-AlSBA-15, indicating non-formation of these species or their presence at levels lower than the detection limits of XRD. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the SBA-15, Al-SBA-15, and Ni-AlSBA-15 catalysts are depicted in Fig. S1A and B , respectively, and the changes that occurred in the catalysts were quantified as summarized in Table 1. All the catalysts had irreversible type IV isotherms with a uniform H1 hysteresis loop in the relative pressure (P/P0 ) range of 0.5–0.8, with steep adsorption/desorption branches. This clearly indicates the presence of highly ordered mesopores in all the catalysts, in line with the XRD results. The P/P0 positions of the inflation points were clearly related to the mesopore diameter range, whereas the sharpness of the steps indicated the uniformity of the mesopore size distribution [29,34]. The isotherms of both the AlSBA-15 and Ni-AlSBA-15 catalysts were very similar to that of SBA-15, but there were slight variations in their inflections points (i.e., there was a shift towards lower P/P0 values) as well as the N2 adsorption amounts (i.e., lower values). The addition of aluminum and nickel to the SBA-15 silica decreased the total pore volume and the BET surface area of the catalysts, associated with the decrease in the pore diameter and an increase in the wall thickness. This clearly demonstrates that some modification occurred in the tubular channels of SBA-15 during the alumination and ion exchange process. The decline of the BET surface area can be attributed to loss of the (ultra)microporosity and a decrease of the surface roughness via the dissolution-redeposition mechanism [30]. In the case of SBA-15, a slight increase in the diameter of the mesopores and a decrease in wall thickness were observed during the dissolution-redeposition process, which was not observed in the case of AlSBA-15 and Ni-AlSBA-15. This may be because these effects were compensated by alumination of the pore walls. The present results are well supported by the previous literature [3,29,30]. However, no significant variations were observed in the textural properties of Ni-AlSBA-15 compared to AlSBA-15, suggesting that ion exchange does not alter the textural properties. Fig. 1C shows the SEM and TEM images of SBA-15, Al-SBA-15, and Ni-AlSBA-15. The SEM images of all the catalysts showed wheat-like macrostructures with many rod-like domains with uniform sizes [26,34], clearly suggesting that no considerable morphological modifications occurred during the alumination and ion exchange process. Furthermore, similar deductions could be made from the TEM images. The TEM images of all the catalysts showed a 2D hexagonal array of uniform mesoporous channels, which are typical for SBA-15 type materials [3,29,34]. These results are in good agreement with the XRD and N2 sorption studies. Fig. 2 A shows 29Si MAS NMR spectra of SBA-15, AlSBA-15, and Ni-AlSBA-15 catalysts. The 29Si MAS NMR spectrum of SBA-15 showed two broad main signals at around −109ppm and −101ppm. The signal at −109ppm can be attributed to Q4 sites (i.e. Si(OSi)4 units) while the signal at −101ppm is owing to Q3 sites (i.e. Si(OSi)3OH units) [3,35]. In the case of AlSBA-15 and Ni-AlSBA-15 catalysts, a very broad and asymmetric signal appeared at around −107ppm, which clearly suggests that the environment of Si atom changed after alumination. Hamdan et al. [36] assigned the signals at −106, −102 and −92ppm to Q3 (i.e. Si(OSi)3(OAl)), Q2 (i.e. Si(OSi)2(OAl)2), and Q1 (i.e. Si(OSi)1(OAl)3) sites, respectively. Thus, the broad signal observed in the AlSBA-15 and Ni-AlSBA-15 catalysts might be due to the presence of all the above species, which confirms the incorporation of Al in the SBA-15 framework. The 27Al MAS NMR spectrum of AlSBA-15 showed only one broad signal centered at 50ppm, whereas Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst showed two broad signals centered at 49 and −3ppm, as shown in Fig. 2B. The signal observed at 49–50ppm is ascribed to the tetrahedral Al species (i.e. framework Al), while the signal noticed at −3ppm belongs to octahedral Al species (i.e. extra-framework Al) [36–39]. The present results suggest that the entire Al in the AlSBA-15 was well incorporated in the framework of SBA-15, whereas a small amount of Al in the Ni-AlSBA-15 was expelled from the SBA-15 framework. The possible explanation for the formation of extra-framework Al in the final Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst might be due to the acidic nature of nickel nitrate solution used in the ionic exchange process [3,40]. 3.2 Oligomerization of ethylene The effect of the WHSV on the catalytic activity and product distribution profile of the Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst was investigated at the reaction temperature of 200°C and pressure of 10bar, as shown in Fig. 3 A. The change in the ethylene conversion was negligible in the WHSV range of 0.375–0.899h−1. However, the product distribution changed significantly with the WHSV. At the low WHSV of 0.375h−1, the catalyst gave rise to a non-Schulz-Flory type hydrocarbon distribution (i.e., C8 >C6 >C4 >C10+). The C4 content increased with an increase of the WHSV, and Schulz-Flory type distribution (i.e.C4 >C6 >C8 >C10+) was obtained at the high WHSV of 0.899h−1. The formation of cracking products decreased with an increase of the WHSV. The present results suggest that a lower WHSV is more favorable for production of an oligomer mixture with non-Schulz-Flory type distribution. Fig. 3B shows the effect of temperature on the catalytic activity and product distribution profiles of the Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst at 10bar and a WHSV 0.375h−1. The ethylene conversion increased from 87% to 99% with an increase of the reaction temperature from 150 to 180°C, followed by saturation. The Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst gave rise to non-Schulz-Flory type distribution at all reaction temperatures. At 150°C, the major product distribution obtained with the Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst was as follows: C8 >C4 >C6 >C10+, but changed to C8 >C6 >C4 >C10+ with a further increase of the temperature to 180 and 200°C. The change of the product distribution with temperature might result from the involvement of the formed C4 olefins with ethylene in the oligomerization reaction, which is clearly reflected in the variation of the C6 selectivity in the product distribution. The small decrement in the selectivity for C10+ olefins at 200°C compared to at other temperatures might be due to the easy desorption of C4 and C6 olefins from the catalyst surface, which prevents co-oligomerization to form C10+ olefins. No noticeable difference was observed in the formation of the cracked products (i.e., C5, C7, and C9 olefins) and ethane with increasing temperature. Fig. 3C shows the effect of ethylene pressure on the catalytic activity and product distribution profiles obtained with the Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst at 200°C with a WHSV of 0.375h−1. The ethylene conversion was 95% at 5bar and increased with increasing ethylene pressure to reach 99% at 15bar. The olefin distribution (C6 >C8 >C4 >C10+) at 5bar was completely different from that at 10 and 15bar (C8 >C6 >C4 >C10+). The content of C4 olefins decreased with pressure, while the content of C10+ olefins increased with increasing ethylene pressure. In the same way, the content of C6 olefins decreased with a change in the pressure from 5 to 10bar and then increased slightly in the pressure range of 10–15bar. These results indicate that the ethylene pressure plays a critical role in the oligomerization of lower olefins. A small increase in the content of cracked products (C5, C7, and C9 olefins) was observed in the range from 5 to 10bar. Thus, it is concluded that an ethylene pressure of 10bar is sufficient to produce an oligomer mixture with non-Schulz-Flory type distribution. The catalytic activity and product distribution profiles obtained with the Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst as a function of the reaction time were evaluated under conditions of 200°C, 10bar C2H4 pressure, and WHSV=0.375h−1, as shown in Fig. 3D. The Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst was highly active and stable for ethylene oligomerization and almost total ethylene (about 99%) conversion to olefins was achieved without any apparent deactivation. The non-Schulz-Flory type product distribution (C8 >C6 >C4 >C10+) did not change significantly with reaction time and the total C5+ liquid selectivity was around 77%. Initially, the C10+ fraction was about 14%, but increased slightly to 16% after 20h. In addition, the concentration of cracked products (C5, C7, and C9 olefins) was about 6−7%, and did not change significantly with reaction time. The high catalytic activity and stability of the Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst was ascribed to the well-ordered interconnected mesopores, which were large enough to facilitate diffusion of the heavier oligomers [3]. However, Ni-AlSBA-15 itself has a limitation in that the maximum C10+ fraction was lower than 20%. 3.3 Co-oligomerization of oligomeric mixture The oligomeric mixture obtained in the first step mostly contained linear and branched olefins with carbon numbers less than 10 (i.e., around 84–86%, where around 24% constituted dissolved C4 olefins). In order to increase the content of C10+ olefins in the liquid product, further oligomerization of the oligomeric mixture over commercially available ion-exchange acidic resins is an appropriate choice. Commercially available macroporous ion-exchange acidic resins are well known solid acid catalysts for the dimerization and oligomerization of linear as well as branched olefins with carbon numbers from 4 to 9 [41–46]. Herein, we used Amberlyst-35 dry ion exchange resin since it is highly active and selective for the dimerization of C6–C8 branched olefins, which are the major constituents in the present oligomeric mixture. The effect of the catalyst loading with respect to the weight of the oligomeric mixture on the olefin distribution was investigated by keeping the other parameters constant (Fig. 4 A). Increasing the catalyst loading from 2.5 to 5.0wt% caused a significant decrease in the content of the C4 and C6 olefins, whereas the content of C8 olefins increased slightly and that of the C10+ olefins increased significantly. The concentrations of C10+ olefins in the oligomeric mixture for respective catalyst loadings of 2.5 and 5wt% were about 37 and 42%. Further increasing the catalyst loading to 10wt% caused the concentration of C10+ olefins to decrease to 19%, and that of the C4 and C6 olefins increased greatly. This result indicates that cracking of the C10+ olefins over the Brønsted acid sites is significant, with a greater number of active sites. Thus, it is concluded that about 5wt% catalyst loading is optimum for maximizing the C10+ fraction, and a higher catalyst loading eventually led to cracking of the C10+ olefins to lower C4 and C6 olefins. Fig. 4B shows the effect of the reaction temperature on the olefin distribution. The Amberlyst-35 dry catalyst produced around 34% C10+ olefins at 80°C. With an increase of the reaction temperature from 80 to 100°C, the C10+ olefin fraction increased to 42%. A further rise in temperature to 120°C had an insignificant impact on the C10+ olefins (43%) in the oligomeric mixture. Moreover, with increasing reaction temperature, there was a continuous decrease of the C4–C6 olefins with a small increase of the cracked products (C7 and C9). The C8 olefin fraction increased slightly after the reaction, and was not significantly affected by the reaction temperature. These results indicate that C4–C6 olefins are deeply involved in the co-oligomerization reaction to form larger olefins at this reaction temperature, whereas higher temperatures were required for co-oligomerization of C8 olefins. At higher reaction temperatures, however, side reactions such as cracking of higher olefins occurred more readily than co-oligomerization [46,47]. Thus, about 100°C is the optimum reaction temperature for obtaining the maximum C10+ fraction without significant accompanying cracking reactions. The effect of reaction time on the olefin distribution at 100°C was also investigated, as shown in Fig. 4C. After 12h of reaction, the C10+ fraction increased to 32% with a slight increase of the C8 fraction. Further increasing the reaction time to 24h and 48h resulted in an increase of the C10+ olefins to 42 and 47%, respectively. The C4 and C6 olefins decreased proportionally with reaction time. These results indicate clearly that formation of C10+ was initiated by co-oligomerization of C4 and C6 olefins. Since, the increase of the C10+ fraction was somewhat limited, 24h of reaction time was optimum for obtaining the maximum C10+ fraction. The effect of N2 pressures from 10 to 30bar on the olefin distribution was evaluated, as shown in Fig. 4D. At 10bar N2 pressure, the fraction of C10+ olefins was around 35% and this increased to 38% at 20bar. Further increasing the N2 pressure to 30bar enhanced the formation of C10+ olefins to 42% with a slight decrease of the C4–C8 olefins. These results indicate that high N2 pressure is favorable for co-oligomerization of the C4–C8 olefin mixture. In summary, the optimum reaction conditions for co-oligomerization of the oligomeric mixture over the Amberlyst-35 dry catalyst are as follows: catalyst loading of 5wt%, reaction temperature of 100°C, reaction pressure of 30bar, and reaction time of 24h. Under the optimized reaction conditions, the fraction of the C5+ liquid product was higher than 98%, where C10+ olefins constituted about 42%. Although Amberlyst-35 ion-exchange resin was found to be highly effective for co-oligomerization of the C4–C8 olefin mixture in a batch reaction, the catalyst stability and recyclability are also very important in heterogeneous catalysis. In order to evaluate the reusability of the Amberlyst-35 dry catalyst, the catalytic activity of the recovered catalyst was compared with that of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 4E). The used catalyst was obtained via simple filtration of the reaction mixture using a Buchner funnel, whereas the regenerated catalyst was obtained by washing with n-heptane followed by ethanol and subsequent oven drying at 80°C for 15h. The used catalyst gave rise to a much lower C10+ fraction (33%), while the regenerated catalyst produced a C10+ fraction (39%) similar to that obtained with the fresh catalyst (42%). To evaluate the observed differences in the catalyst activity, the catalysts were characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. 5 ). The fresh Amberlyst-35 catalyst degraded in three steps; the first step (<200°C) can be attributed to the loss of physically adsorbed molecular water, the second (i.e., 200–400°C) may be related to depolymerisation of the polystyrene chains and decomposition of the sulfonic acid groups, and the third is (>400°C) attributed to breakdown of the polymer backbone with degradation of divinylbenzene [48–50]. The regenerated catalyst gave rise to TGA patterns analogous to those of the fresh catalyst with insignificant changes in the weight loss, confirming that no major changes in the composition and thermal stability of the catalyst occurred even after the regeneration process. However, the TGA profile of the used Amberlyst-35 catalyst showed a greater difference in weight loss compared to the two aforementioned catalysts. The major difference in the used catalyst might be due to the olefins adsorbed on the catalyst, which would result in fewer available active sites (i.e., some of the active sites might be covered by the strongly adsorbed heavier olefins). Thus, it is desirable to regenerate the used Amberlyst-35 catalyst by washing with solvent followed by drying for use in subsequent runs. 4 Conclusions An integrated process for the production of jet-fuel range olefins from ethylene was established by combining two processes, i.e., oligomerization of ethylene over Ni-AlSBA-15 and co-oligomerization of the oligomeric mixture over Amberlyst-35 dry ion-exchange resin. The bi-functional Ni-AlSBA-15 (1.9wt% Ni and Si/Al=9) mesoporous material gave rise to about 99% ethylene conversion with non-Schulz-Flory type olefin distribution (C8 >C6 >C4 >C10+), which was achieved under the mild conditions of 200°C, 10bar, and 0.375h−1 WHSV. Subsequently, application of the Amberlyst-35 dry catalyst produced about 98% of liquid olefins from the as-synthesized oligomeric mixture under the optimized reaction conditions (i.e., catalyst loading: 5wt%, temperature: 100°C, N2 pressure: 30bar, and reaction time: 24h), where 42% corresponded to C10+ olefins. The catalytic activity of the used Amberlyst-35 catalyst was almost identical to that of the fresh catalyst after washing with n-heptane and drying. Using the present integrated process, 99% of ethylene can be converted to about 98% liquid olefins (i.e., C5+ olefins), where 42% of the olefins have carbon chains longer than 10 carbon atoms. coredata.dc:description: An integrated process for the production of jet-fuel range olefins from ethylene was established by combining oligomerization of ethylene over the bifunctional Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst with subsequent co-oligomerization of the liquid oligomer mixture over an Amberlyst-35 ion-exchange resin catalyst. The mesoporous Ni-AlSBA-15 catalyst was prepared by alumination of SBA-15 using sodium aluminate, followed by sequential ion exchange with NH4 + and Ni2+ ions. The Ni-AlSBA-15 (1.9wt% Ni and Si/Al=9) catalyst showed good catalytic activity, yielding over 99% ethylene conversion with non-Schulz-Flory type distribution of the generated hydrocarbons (C8 >C6 >C4 >C10+) and high stability at 200°C and 10bar at a weight hourly space velocity of 0.375h−1 for 60h. Co-oligomerization of the as-synthesized liquid oligomer mixture over Amberlyst-35 ion-exchange resin under the optimized reaction conditions (5wt% catalyst loading, 100°C, 30bar N2, and 24h of reaction time) generated greater than 98% C5+ liquid product, where the C10+ olefins constituted about 42%. The catalytic activity of the Amberlyst-35 catalyst used was almost identical to that of the fresh catalyst after washing with n-heptane and drying.
coredata.dc:title: An integrated process for production of jet-fuel range olefins from ethylene using Ni-AlSBA-15 and Amberlyst-35 catalysts
